title: Benn Fields
text:
Benjamin "Benn" Fields (born December 17, 1954) is an American former <a href="high%20jumper">high jumper</a>. In 1979 Fields won silver medals at the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201979%20Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> and the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201979%20Soviet%20Spartakiad">Soviet Spartakiad</a>. He won his specialty at the 1980 <a href="United%20States%20Olympic%20Trials%20%28track%20and%20field%29">U.S. Olympic Trials</a>, but missed out on Olympic participation due to the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">American boycott</a>.
Early career.
Fields attended <a href="Washingtonville%20High%20School">Washingtonville High School</a> in <a href="Washingtonville%2C%20New%20York">Washingtonville, New York</a>, where he set school records in both <a href="high%20jump">high jump</a> and <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a>. Originally, he jumped as Ben Fields; he adopted the spelling "Benn" later in his career to make his name more distinctive. In 1972, his <a href="Senior%20%28education%29">senior year</a> at Washingtonville, Fields suffered from a bruised back but recovered fast enough to enter the New York State high school championship meet as one of the favorites in the high jump; he won the state title with a jump of 6 ft 6 in (1.98 m).
After graduating from Washingtonville Fields entered the <a href="State%20University%20of%20New%20York%20at%20New%20Paltz">State University of New York at New Paltz</a>, setting a <a href="State%20University%20of%20New%20York%20Athletic%20Conference">SUNY Athletic Conference</a> record as a <a href="freshman">freshman</a> in 1973 and sharing third place at that year's <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association%23Division%20history">NCAA College Division</a> championships. SUNY New Paltz dropped its track and field program after that year, with Fields moving to <a href="Seton%20Hall%20University">Seton Hall University</a> as a result. While at Seton Hall, he won the 1975 <a href="Penn%20Relays">Penn Relays</a> high jump with a jump of 7 ft  in (2.17 m) and placed fourth at that year's <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Outdoor%20Track%20and%20Field%20Championships">NCAA Division I Championships</a>; he also won the 1975 <a href="IC4A">IC4A</a> high jump title as Seton Hall claimed the team championship. In 1976, his final year at Seton Hall, Fields placed eighth at the NCAA championships and seventh at the <a href="USA%20Outdoor%20Track%20and%20Field%20Championships">national</a> (<a href="Amateur%20Athletic%20Union">AAU</a>) championships. At that summer's <a href="United%20States%20Olympic%20Trials%20%28track%20and%20field%29">U.S. Olympic Trials</a> Fields no-heighted in the final, failing to qualify for the <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics">American team</a>.
Later career.
Fields continued high jumping after graduating from Seton Hall, dedicating himself to qualifying for the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. In 1977 he placed fourth at the AAU championships with a jump of 7 ft 3 in (2.21 m) and was ranked #7 in the United States by "<a href="Track%20%26amp%3B%20Field%20News">Track & Field News</a>" for his first national top 10 ranking. At the 1978 AAU meet Fields cleared 7 ft  in (2.24 m) to place shared second, losing only to former <a href="Men%27s%20high%20jump%20world%20record%20progression">world record holder</a> <a href="Dwight%20Stones">Dwight Stones</a> and tying with former world indoor record holder <a href="Franklin%20Jacobs">Franklin Jacobs</a>. He set his personal best, 2.30 m (7 ft  in), in <a href="Valpara%C3%ADso">Valparaíso</a> on November 1, 1978; "Track & Field News" ranked him third in the United States and sixth in the world that year.
Fields won the national indoor championship title at the 1979 AAU <a href="USA%20Indoor%20Track%20and%20Field%20Championships">indoor championships</a>, jumping a meeting record 7 ft  in (2.25 m) and edging out Jacobs and James Frazier on fewer misses; Stones, the previous year's champion, had been declared a professional and thus wasn't eligible to jump. At the outdoor championships Jacobs in turn won from Fields on countback as both cleared 7 ft 5 in (2.26 m); Jacobs, who had had a mediocre outdoor season until then, only narrowly missed at 7 ft 7 in. That summer Fields represented the United States at the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201979%20Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> in <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">San Juan, Puerto Rico</a>, and then the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201979%20Soviet%20Spartakiad">Soviet Spartakiad</a> in Moscow; he won silver medals in both meets. At the Pan American Games he only cleared 2.19 m (7 ft  in), but still placed second behind Jacobs; at the Spartakiad, which as a dress rehearsal for the following year's <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> was inviting non-Soviet athletes for the first time, he jumped 2.24 m (7 ft  in) and lost to the Soviet Union's <a href="Aleksandr%20Grigoryev%20%28athlete%29">Aleksandr Grigoryev</a> on more misses. Fields's best jump in 1979 was 2.27 m (7 ft  in), which he jumped in <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a> on June 7; he defeated world record holder <a href="Vladimir%20Yashchenko">Vladimir Yashchenko</a> in that competition.
Fields remained in good shape in 1980 and was disappointed with the American decision to <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">boycott</a> the Olympics in Moscow. He skipped that year's national championships, but eventually decided to compete at the Olympic Trials (which were held separately); in windy conditions, he won the Trials with a jump of 7 ft 5 in (2.26 m), but due to the boycott he and the other qualifiers didn't get to compete at the Olympics. "Track & Field News" ranked him a career-best fifth in the world that year, and first in the United States; it was his only national #1 ranking.
Although Fields was never world-ranked again after 1980, he continued his jumping career. At the 1982 U.S: outdoor championships, he placed second behind <a href="Milton%20Ottey">Milton Ottey</a>, a Canadian. As the top United States jumper, he was the American champion. 1982 marked the last time Fields was ranked in the national top ten; he attempted to qualify for the Olympics again at the 1984 Trials, but no-heighted in the qualification round.
Recognition.
Fields qualified for the 1980 U.S. Olympic team but was unable to compete due to the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">boycott</a>. He did however receive one of 461 <a href="List%20of%20Congressional%20Gold%20Medal%20recipients">Congressional Gold Medal</a>s created especially for the spurned athletes.
Fields was inducted in the <a href="Seton%20Hall%20Pirates">Seton Hall Pirates</a> Hall of Fame in 1982 and in the <a href="New%20Paltz%20Hawks">New Paltz Hawks</a> Hall of Fame in 2005.
